definition: the opposite of something
a contrast between two things
a written statement that you swear is true, and that can be used as evidence in court
one of the two horns that grow on the head of male deer
feeling worried or nervous
causing worry; showing worry
wanting something very much
the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body once it has passed through the lungs
having the same, or nearly the same, meaning
so closely connected with something that the two things appear to be the same
showing no interest or enthusiasm
a food or drug that is said to give people a strong desire to have sex
sexual desire
having, costing or measuring a particular amount each
a condition in which somebody stops breathing for a short time, especially while they are sleeping
Christian religious texts that are related to the Bible but not officially considered to be part of it
writings that are not considered to be what somebody claims they are
well known, but probably not true
feeling or showing that you are sorry for doing something wrong or for causing a problem
to say that you are sorry for doing something wrong or causing a problem
a word or statement saying sorry for something that has been done wrong or that causes a problem
information that you cannot go to a meeting or must leave early
if you say that you make no apology/apologies for something, you mean that you do not feel that you have said or done anything wrong
in the opposite direction to the movement of the hands of a clock
the sudden loss of the ability to feel or move, normally caused by an injury in the brain
giving the impression that you feel you are better and more moral than other people
to get information or a reaction from somebody, often with difficulty
the mark ( ’ ) used to show that one or more letters or numbers have been left out, as in she’s for she is and ’63 for 1963
the mark ( ’ ) used before or after the letter ‘s’ to show that something belongs to somebody, as in Sam’s watch and the horses’ tails
the mark ( ’ ) used before the letter ‘s’ to show the plural of a letter or number, as in How many 3’s are there in 9? and There are two m’s in ‘comma’.
the highest or most perfect development of something
the best time in somebody’s life or career
a formal statement that a person has become a god
to make somebody feel extremely shocked and feel very strongly that something is bad
extremely bad, especially from a moral point of view
very bad; of very poor quality
to make somebody calmer or less angry by giving them what they want
to give a country what it wants in order to avoid war
still in existence
to add something to the end of a piece of writing
a thing that is added or attached to something larger or more important
part of a living thing, such as an insect, that sticks out and has a particular function
the act of walking around while you are asleep
a serious medical condition in which the appendix becomes painful and larger than normal
physical desire for food
a strong desire for something
a small amount of food or a drink that you have before a meal
a small dish of food that is served before the main course of a meal
that smells or looks attractive; making you feel hungry or thirsty
to show your approval of somebody/something by clapping your hands (= hitting your open hands together several times)
to express praise for somebody/something because you approve of them or it
the noise made by a group of people clapping their hands and sometimes shouting to show their approval or pleasure
